Description: A domed sealing for an unknown object, probably a document: oval impressions, fifteen in number, some incomplete, from three intaglio gems. These appear to be of a lion to right with a plant, a bust of Osiris to right, wearing the atef crown and a broad collar, and a two-handled vase. A personal name is incised in demotic between the impressions. Unfired pale yellow-brown mud.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Society. Roman, probably second century AD. Possibly the mark of a witness who had no seal, the personal name Pa-di-Amen is incised in demotic between the impressions: I am grateful to Carol Andrews for reading this. Comparandum: For the Osiris bust, compare an intaglio of much greater quality on a bronze ring in the Petrie Museum, uc2457 (Walker and Higgs 2001: no. 38), thought to be a portrait of a Ptolemy.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3644)
